title: 111_s1144
content: The "Rural Transit Improvement and Flexibility Act of 2009" amends Section 5311(c)(2) of title 49, United States Code, increasing the formula grants for other than urbanized areas to 25 percent and 75 percent respectively. It also allows for flexible use of elderly and disabled funding. Section 5310 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allow states to use up to 25 percent of apportioned funds for operating costs of equipment and facilities funded under this section. Grants for operating assistance cannot exceed 50 percent of the net operating costs of the project. The Secretary determines the net operating costs of the project. States can use up to 25% of funds for operating costs. Grants for operating assistance cannot exceed 50% of the net operating costs. States described in section 120(b) of title 23 receive a Government share of 62.5% of the net operating costs. PILOT PROGRAM FOR TRANSIT CENTERS IN SMALLER CITIES AND TOWNS. The Secretary will establish a pilot program for grants to eligible States to create transit centers in urbanized areas with a population under 200,000. The purpose is to improve transit service in areas that historically lacked attention to transit development. The Secretary will establish a pilot program for grants to eligible States with low population density to improve transit service. Definitions for 'eligible State', 'recipient', and 'subrecipient' are provided. Administrative procedures will be developed to streamline the implementation of the program. The Secretary will develop procedures to streamline the implementation of the grant program and minimize regulatory burden. Funds will be distributed to establish centers in eligible States by awarding grants before the end of fiscal year 2012. The grant program aims to establish centers in eligible States by awarding grants before the end of fiscal year 2015. Recipients can use up to 10% of the funds for administration costs, with the rest allocated for capital expenses like buildings. The program is for capital expenses such as buildings, maintenance facilities, transit vehicle stops, and parking spaces. The government will cover 100% of the capital costs. Funding of $25,000,000 for 2010 and $50,000,000 for each year from 2011 to 2015 is available from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund.
